Wimbledon is played in the last week of June and the first week of July, and has been chronologically the third of the four [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] tournaments of the tennis [[Season (sports)|season]] since 1987.<ref name=WProfile/> The event was not held from 1915 to 1918 because of World War I and again from 1940 to 1945 because of World War II.<ref name=2009aetlcFinals>{{cite web|work=wimbledon.org|publisher=[[IBM]], [[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club]]|title=Men's Singles Finals| url =http://aeltc2009.wimbledon.org/en_GB/about/history/rolls/menroll.html| accessdate =2009-06-24}}</ref>
The Gentlemen's Singles' rules have undergone several changes since the first edition. From [[1878 Wimbledon Championship|1878]] until [[1921 Wimbledon Championships|1921]], the event started with a [[Single-elimination tournament|knockout]] phase, the All Comers' Singles, whose winner then faced the defending champion in a [[Glossary of tennis#Challenge Round|challenge round]]. The All Comers' winner was automatically awarded the title six times ([[1879 Wimbledon Championships|1879]], [[1887 Wimbledon Championships|1887]], [[1891 Wimbledon Championships|1891]], [[1895 Wimbledon Championships|1895]], [[1907 Wimbledon Championships|1907]], [[1908 Wimbledon Championships|1908]]) in the absence of the previous year's champion. The challenge round system was abolished with the [[1922 Wimbledon Championships|1922]] edition.<ref name=Barrett>{{Cite book | title =100 Wimbledon Championships: A Celebration |isbn=978-0-00218-220-1 |publisher=Collins Willow|first=John|last=Barrett|authorlink =John Barrett (tennis)|year=1986}}</ref> Since the first championships, all matches have been played at the [[Tennis score#Scoring a set|best-of-five sets]]. Between 1877 and [[1883 Wimbledon Championship|1883]], the winner of the next game at five games [[Glossary of tennis#All|â all]] took the set in every match except the All Comers' final, and the challenge round, which were won with six games and a two games advantage. All sets were decided in this [[Glossary of tennis#Advantage format|advantage format]] from [[1884 Wimbledon Championships|1884]] to [[1970 Wimbledon Championships|1970]].<ref name=Barrett/> The [[Glossary of tennis#Lingering death|lingering death]] best of 12 points [[Tennis score#Scoring a tiebreak game|tie-break]] was introduced in [[1971 Wimbledon Championships|1971]] for the first four sets, played at eight games all until [[1978 Wimbledon Championships|1978]] and at six games all since [[1979 Wimbledon Championships|1979]].<ref name=Barrett/><ref name=Tie-break>{{cite web|first=John|last= Roberts |work=[[The Independent]]|title=Tennis: Fast, fan friendly - but full of faults | url =http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/tennis-fast-fan-friendly--but-full-of-faults-1169793.html| date=1998-08-05| accessdate =2009-06-24}}</ref><ref name=SuddenLingering>{{cite web|work=[[The Age]]|publisher=The Age Company Ltd|title=Breaking with tradition| url =http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/01/24/1074732652848.html?from=storyrhs| date=2004-01-25|accessdate =2009-07-27}}</ref>
Since 1949, the Gentlemen's Singles champion has received a miniature replica of the event's trophy, a [[silver-gilt]] cup created in 1887 with the engraved inscription: "The All England Lawn Tennis Club Single Handed Champion of the World".<ref name=2009aetlcTrophy>{{cite web|work=wimbledon.org|publisher=[[IBM]], [[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club]]|title=About Wimbledon - History: The trophies| url =http://aeltc2009.wimbledon.org/en_GB/about/history/trophies.html| accessdate =2009-06-24}}</ref> New singles champions are traditionally elected honorary members of the AELTC by the club's committee.{{Ref label|McEnroeMembership|c|c}}<ref name=2009aetlcClub>{{cite web|work=wimbledon.org|publisher=[[IBM]], [[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club]]|title=About Wimbledon - The All England Lawn Tennis Club| url =http://www.wimbledon.org/en_GB/about/guide/club.html| accessdate =2010-12-11}}</ref> In 2009, the Gentlemen's Singles winner received [[prize money]] of [[Pound sterling|Â£]]850,000.<ref name=2009aetlcPrize>{{cite web|work=wimbledon.org|publisher=[[IBM]], [[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club]]|title=2009 Prize Money| url =http://aeltc2009.wimbledon.org/en_GB/about/pdf/Prize_Money_2009.pdf|format=PDF| accessdate =2009-06-24}}</ref>
In the Amateur Era, [[William Renshaw]] (1881â1886, 1889) holds the record for most titles in the Gentlemen's Singles, with seven victories. Renshaw's wins, however, came within the challenge round format, and he won the event only twice after going through a complete draw. Renshaw also holds the record for most consecutive titles with six from (1881 to 1886). The record for most consecutive and most wins post challenge round during the Amateur Era is [[Fred Perry]] (1934â1936).<ref name=2009aetlcFinals/>
